description: From Middle French intelligent, from Latin intellegēns (“discerning”), present active participle of intellegō (“understand, comprehend”), itself from inter (“between”) + legō (“choose, pick out, read”).

adjectives.description: intelligent (comparative more intelligent or intelligenter, superlative most intelligent or intelligentest)

entries.meaning: Of high or especially quick cognitive capacity, bright.

examples: The engineer had a very intelligent design proposal for the new car.
The general devised an intelligent strategy for the southern campaign.
My girlfriend and I had an intelligent conversation.

entries.meaning: Having at least a similar level of brain power to humankind.
Having an environment-sensing automatically-invoked built-in computer capability.
